member.name: T:Nest.IDateHistogramCompositeAggregationSource
member.summary: A values source that can be applied on date values to build fixed size interval over the values. The interval parameter defines a date/time expression that determines how values should be transformed. For instance an interval set to month will translate any values to its closest month interval..

member.summary: Return a formatted date string as the key instead an epoch long
member.remarks: Valid for Elasticsearch 6.3.0+

member.name: T:Nest.IHistogramCompositeAggregationSource
member.summary: A value source that can be applied on numeric values to build fixed size interval over the values. The interval parameter defines how the numeric values should be transformed. For instance an interval set to 5 will translate any numeric values to its closest interval, a value of 101 would be translated to 100 which is the key for the interval between 100 and 105.

member.name: P:Nest.FiltersAggregation.OtherBucket
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to add a bucket to the response which will contain all documents that do not match any of the given filters. When set to true, the other bucket will be returned either in a bucket (named "_other_" by default) if named filters are being used, or as the last bucket if anonymous filters are being used When set to false, does not compute the other bucket.

member.name: P:Nest.FiltersAggregation.OtherBucketKey
member.summary: Gets or sets the key for the other bucket to a value other than the default "_other_". Setting this parameter will implicitly set the parameter to true

member.name: M:Nest.FiltersAggregationDescriptor`1.OtherBucket(System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Adds a bucket to the response which will contain all documents that do not match any of the given filters. When set to true, the other bucket will be returned either in a bucket (named "_other_" by default) if named filters are being used, or as the last bucket if anonymous filters are being used When set to false, does not compute the other bucket.
member.param: whether to set the other bucket
member.returns: the

member.name: M:Nest.FiltersAggregationDescriptor`1.OtherBucketKey(System.String)

member.name: M:Nest.SignificantTextAggregationDescriptor`1.PercentageScore(System.Func{Nest.PercentageScoreHeuristicDescriptor,Nest.IPercentageScoreHeuristic})
member.summary:
Use percentage to calculate significance score.
A simple calculation of the number of documents in the foreground sample with a term divided by the number of documents in the background with the term. By default this produces a score greater than zero and less than one.

member.name: T:Nest.IMedianAbsoluteDeviationAggregation
member.summary:
This single-value aggregation approximates the median absolute deviation of its search results.
Median absolute deviation is a measure of variability. It is a robust statistic, meaning that it is useful for describing data that may have outliers, or may not be normally distributed. For such data it can be more descriptive than standard deviation.
It is calculated as the median of each data point’s deviation from the median of the entire sample. That is, for a random variable X, the median absolute deviation is median(|median(X) - Xi|).
Be sure to read the Elasticsearch documentation on {ref_current}/search-aggregations-metrics-median-absolute-deviation-aggregation.html[Median Absolute Deviation Aggregation]

member.name: P:Nest.IMedianAbsoluteDeviationAggregation.Compression
member.summary: TDigest algorithm component that controls memory usage and approximation error. By increasing the compression value, you can increase the accuracy at the cost of more memory. Larger compression values also make the algorithm slower since the underlying tree data structure grows in size, resulting in more expensive operations. The default compression value is 100.

member.name: T:Nest.IBucketSortAggregation
member.summary: A parent pipeline aggregation which sorts the buckets of its parent multi-bucket aggregation. Zero or more sort fields may be specified together with the corresponding sort order. Each bucket may be sorted based on its _key, _count or its sub-aggregations. In addition, parameters from and size may be set in order to truncate the result buckets.

member.name: T:Nest.ICustomNormalizer
member.summary:
Normalizers are similar to analyzers except that they may only emit a single token. As a consequence, they do not have a tokenizer and only accept a subset of the available char filters and token filters. Only the filters that work on a per-character basis are allowed. For instance a lowercasing filter would be allowed, but not a stemming filter, which needs to look at the keyword as a whole.
Elasticsearch does not ship with built-in normalizers so far, so the only way to create one is through composing a custom one

member.name: P:Nest.ICustomNormalizer.CharFilter
member.summary: Char filters to normalize the keyword

member.name: P:Nest.ICustomNormalizer.Filter
member.summary: An optional list of logical / registered name of token filters.

member.summary: Char filters to normalize the keyword

member.name: P:Nest.CustomNormalizer.Filter
member.summary: An optional list of logical / registered name of token filters.

member.name: M:Nest.NormalizersDescriptor.Custom(System.String,System.Func{Nest.CustomNormalizerDescriptor,Nest.ICustomNormalizer})
member.summary: Elasticsearch does not ship with built-in normalizers so far, so the only way to get one is by building a custom one. Custom normalizers take a list of char character filters and a list of token filters.

member.name: T:Nest.IcuCollationAlternate
member.summary: Sets the alternate handling for strength quaternary to be either shifted or non-ignorable. Which boils down to ignoring punctuation and whitespace.
member.remarks: Requires analysis-icu plugin to be installed

member.name: T:Nest.IcuCollationCaseFirst
member.summary: Controls which case is sorted first when case is not ignored for strength tertiary. The default depends on the collation.
member.remarks: Requires analysis-icu plugin to be installed

member.name: T:Nest.IcuCollationDecomposition
member.summary: Setting this decomposition property to canonical allows the Collator to handle unnormalized text properly, producing the same results as if the text were normalized. If no is set, it is the user’s responsibility to insure that all text is already in the appropriate form before a comparison or before getting a CollationKey. Adjusting decomposition mode allows the user to select between faster and more complete collation behavior. Since a great many of the world’s languages do not require text normalization, most locales set no as the default decomposition mode.
member.remarks: Requires analysis-icu plugin to be installed

member.name: T:Nest.IcuCollationStrength
member.summary: The strength property determines the minimum level of difference considered significant during comparison. See also: http://icu-project.org/apiref/icu4j/com/ibm/icu/text/Collator.html
member.remarks: Requires analysis-icu plugin to be installed

member.name: F:Nest.IcuCollationStrength.Primary
member.summary: Typically, this is used to denote differences between base characters (for example, "a" < "b"). It is the strongest difference. For example, dictionaries are divided into different sections by base character.

member.name: F:Nest.IcuCollationStrength.Secondary
member.summary: Accents in the characters are considered secondary differences (for example, "as" < "às" < "at"). Other differences between letters can also be considered secondary differences, depending on the language. A secondary difference is ignored when there is a primary difference anywhere in the strings.

member.name: F:Nest.IcuCollationStrength.Tertiary
member.summary: Upper and lower case differences in characters are distinguished at tertiary strength (for example, "ao" < "Ao" < "aò"). In addition, a variant of a letter differs from the base form on the tertiary strength (such as "A" and "Ⓐ"). Another example is the difference between large and small Kana. A tertiary difference is ignored when there is a primary or secondary difference anywhere in the strings.

member.name: F:Nest.IcuCollationStrength.Quaternary
member.summary: When punctuation is ignored (see Ignoring Punctuations in the User Guide) at PRIMARY to TERTIARY strength, an additional strength level can be used to distinguish words with and without punctuation (for example, "ab" < "a-b" < "aB"). This difference is ignored when there is a PRIMARY, SECONDARY or TERTIARY difference. The QUATERNARY strength should only be used if ignoring punctuation is required.

member.name: F:Nest.IcuCollationStrength.Indentical
member.summary: When all other strengths are equal, the IDENTICAL strength is used as a tiebreaker. The Unicode code point values of the NFD form of each string are compared, just in case there is no difference. For example, Hebrew cantellation marks are only distinguished at this strength. This strength should be used sparingly, as only code point value differences between two strings is an extremely rare occurrence. Using this strength substantially decreases the performance for both comparison and collation key generation APIs. This strength also increases the size of the collation key.

member.name: T:Nest.IIcuCollationTokenFilter
member.summary: Collations are used for sorting documents in a language-specific word order. The icu_collation token filter is available to all indices and defaults to using the DUCET collation, which is a best-effort attempt at language-neutral sorting. Part of the `analysis-icu` plugin: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/plugins/current/analysis-icu.html
member.remarks: Requires analysis-icu plugin to be installed

Adjusting decomposition mode allows the user to select between faster and more complete collation behavior. member.name: T:Nest.IIcuTokenizer
member.summary: Tokenizes text into words on word boundaries, as defined in UAX #29: Unicode Text Segmentation. It behaves much like the standard tokenizer, but adds better support for some Asian languages by using a dictionary-based approach to identify words in Thai, Lao, Chinese, Japanese, and Korean, and using custom rules to break Myanmar and Khmer text into syllables.
member.remarks: Requires analysis-icu plugin to be installed

member.name: P:Nest.IKuromojiTokenizer.NBestCost
member.summary: The nbest_cost parameter specifies an additional Viterbi cost. The KuromojiTokenizer will include all tokens in Viterbi paths that are within the nbest_cost value of the best path.

member.name: P:Nest.IKuromojiTokenizer.NBestExamples
member.summary: The nbest_examples can be used to find a nbest_cost value based on examples. For example, a value of /箱根山-箱根/成田空港-成田/ indicates that in the texts, 箱根山 (Mt. Hakone) and 成田空港 (Narita Airport) we’d like a cost that gives is us 箱根 (Hakone) and 成田 (Narita).

member.name: T:Nest.IAsciiFoldingTokenFilter

A token filter of type asciifolding that converts alphabetic, numeric, and symbolic Unicode characters which are

member.name: T:Nest.IShingleTokenFilter
member.summary:
A token filter of type shingle that constructs shingles (token n-grams) from a token stream.
In other words, it creates combinations of tokens as a single token.

member.name: P:Nest.IShingleTokenFilter.FillerToken
member.summary: The string to use as a replacement for each position at which there is no actual token in the stream. For instance this string is used if the position increment is greater than one when a stop filter is used together with the shingle filter. Defaults to "_"

member.name: P:Nest.IShingleTokenFilter.MaxShingleSize
member.summary: The maximum shingle size. Defaults to 2.

member.name: P:Nest.IShingleTokenFilter.MinShingleSize
member.summary: The minimum shingle size. Defaults to 2.

member.name: P:Nest.IShingleTokenFilter.OutputUnigrams
member.summary: If true the output will contain the input tokens (unigrams) as well as the shingles. Defaults to true.

member.name: P:Nest.IShingleTokenFilter.OutputUnigramsIfNoShingles
member.summary:
If output_unigrams is false the output will contain the input tokens (unigrams) if no shingles are available.
Note if output_unigrams is set to true this setting has no effect. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Nest.ShingleTokenFilter.FillerToken
member.summary: The string to use as a replacement for each position at which there is no actual token in the stream. For instance this string is used if the position increment is greater than one when a stop filter is used together with the shingle filter. Defaults to "_"

member.summary: A token filter of type stop that removes stop words from token streams.

member.name: P:Nest.IStopTokenFilter.IgnoreCase
member.summary: Set to true to lower case all words first. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Nest.IStopTokenFilter.RemoveTrailing
member.summary: Set to false in order to not ignore the last term of a search if it is a stop word. This is very useful for the completion suggester as a query like green a can be extended to green apple even though you remove stop words in general. Defaults to true.

member.name: P:Nest.IStopTokenFilter.StopWords
member.summary: A list of stop words to use. Defaults to `_english_` stop words.

member.name: P:Nest.IStopTokenFilter.StopWordsPath
member.summary: A path (either relative to config location, or absolute) to a stopwords file configuration. Each stop word should be in its own "line" (separated by a line break). The file must be UTF-8 encoded.

member.summary: A token filter of type fingerprint The fingerprint token filter that emits a single token which is useful for fingerprinting a body of text, and/or providing a token that can be clustered on. It does this by sorting the tokens, deduplicating and then concatenating them back into a single token.

member.name: M:Nest.TokenFiltersDescriptor.KuromojiStemmer(System.String,System.Func{Nest.KuromojiStemmerTokenFilterDescriptor,Nest.IKuromojiStemmerTokenFilter})
member.summary: The kuromoji_stemmer token filter normalizes common katakana spelling variations ending in a long sound character by removing this character (U+30FC). Only full-width katakana characters are supported. Part of the `analysis-kuromoji` plugin: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/plugins/current/analysis-kuromoji.html

member.name: M:Nest.TokenFiltersDescriptor.KuromojiReadingForm(System.String,System.Func{Nest.KuromojiReadingFormTokenFilterDescriptor,Nest.IKuromojiReadingFormTokenFilter})

member.name: M:Nest.TokenFiltersDescriptor.KuromojiPartOfSpeech(System.String,System.Func{Nest.KuromojiPartOfSpeechTokenFilterDescriptor,Nest.IKuromojiPartOfSpeechTokenFilter})
member.summary: The kuromoji_part_of_speech token filter removes tokens that match a set of part-of-speech tags. Part of the `analysis-kuromoji` plugin: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/plugins/current/analysis-kuromoji.html

member.name: M:Nest.TokenFiltersDescriptor.IcuCollation(System.String,System.Func{Nest.IcuCollationTokenFilterDescriptor,Nest.IIcuCollationTokenFilter})
member.summary: Collations are used for sorting documents in a language-specific word order. The icu_collation token filter is available to all indices and defaults to using the DUCET collation, which is a best-effort attempt at language-neutral sorting. Part of the `analysis-icu` plugin: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/plugins/current/analysis-icu.html

member.name: T:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter
member.summary: Named word_delimiter, it Splits words into subwords and performs optional transformations on subword groups. Unlike the word_delimiter this token filter named word_delimiter_graph correctly handles multi terms expansion at query time.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.CatenateAll
member.summary: If true causes all subword parts to be catenated: "wi-fi-4000" ⇒ "wifi4000". Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.CatenateNumbers
member.summary: If true causes maximum runs of number parts to be catenated: "500-42" ⇒ "50042". Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.CatenateWords
member.summary: If true causes maximum runs of word parts to be catenated: "wi-fi" ⇒ "wifi". Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.GenerateNumberParts
member.summary: If true causes number subwords to be generated: "500-42" ⇒ "500" "42". Defaults to true.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.GenerateWordParts
member.summary: If true causes parts of words to be generated: "PowerShot" ⇒ "Power" "Shot". Defaults to true.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.PreserveOriginal
member.summary: If true includes original words in subwords: "500-42" ⇒ "500-42" "500" "42". Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.ProtectedWords
member.summary: A list of protected words from being delimiter.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.ProtectedWordsPath
member.summary: protected_words_path which resolved to a file configured with protected words (one on each line). Automatically resolves to config/ based location if exists.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.SplitOnCaseChange
member.summary: If true causes "PowerShot" to be two tokens; ("Power-Shot" remains two parts regards). Defaults to true.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.SplitOnNumerics
member.summary: If true causes "j2se" to be three tokens; "j" "2" "se". Defaults to true.

member.name: P:Nest.IWordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.StemEnglishPossessive
member.summary: If true causes trailing "'s" to be removed for each subword: "O’Neil’s" ⇒ "O", "Neil". Defaults to true.

member.summary: A custom type mapping table

member.summary: A path to a custom type mapping table file

member.summary: If true causes maximum runs of number parts to be catenated: "500-42" ⇒ "50042". Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Nest.WordDelimiterGraphTokenFilter.PreserveOriginal
member.summary: If true includes original words in subwords: "500-42" ⇒ "500-42" "500" "42". Defaults to false.

member.name: T:Nest.ICharGroupTokenizer
member.summary: A tokenizer that breaks text into terms whenever it encounters a character which is in a defined set. It is mostly useful for cases where a simple custom tokenization is desired, and the overhead of use of is not acceptable.

member.name: P:Nest.ICharGroupTokenizer.TokenizeOnCharacters
member.summary: A list containing a list of characters to tokenize the string on. Whenever a character from this list is encountered, a new token is started. This accepts either single characters like eg. -, or character groups: whitespace, letter, digit, punctuation, symbol.

member.name: P:Nest.CharGroupTokenizer.TokenizeOnCharacters
member.summary: A list containing a list of characters to tokenize the string on. Whenever a character from this list is encountered, a new token is started. This accepts either single characters like eg. -, or character groups: whitespace, letter, digit, punctuation, symbol.

member.name: M:Nest.CharGroupTokenizerDescriptor.TokenizeOnCharacters(System.String[])
member.summary: A list containing a list of characters to tokenize the string on. Whenever a character from this list is encountered, a new token is started. This accepts either single characters like eg. -, or character groups: whitespace, letter, digit, punctuation, symbol.

member.name: M:Nest.CharGroupTokenizerDescriptor.TokenizeOnCharacters(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: A list containing a list of characters to tokenize the string on. Whenever a character from this list is encountered, a new token is started. This accepts either single characters like eg. -, or character groups: whitespace, letter, digit, punctuation, symbol.

member.name: T:Nest.IKeywordTokenizer
member.summary: A tokenizer of type keyword that emits the entire input as a single input.

member.name: P:Nest.IKeywordTokenizer.BufferSize
member.summary: The term buffer size. Defaults to 256.

member.name: P:Nest.KeywordTokenizer.BufferSize
member.summary: The term buffer size. Defaults to 256.

member.name: M:Nest.KeywordTokenizerDescriptor.BufferSize(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: The term buffer size. Defaults to 256.

member.name: T:Nest.ILetterTokenizer
member.summary:
A tokenizer of type letter that divides text at non-letters. That’s to say, it defines tokens as maximal strings of adjacent letters.
Note, this does a decent job for most European languages, but does a terrible job for some Asian languages, where words are not separated by spaces.

member.name: T:Nest.ILowercaseTokenizer
member.summary:
A tokenizer of type lowercase that performs the function of Letter Tokenizer and Lower Case Token Filter together.
It divides text at non-letters and converts them to lower case.
While it is functionally equivalent to the combination of Letter Tokenizer and Lower Case Token Filter,
there is a performance advantage to doing the two tasks at once, hence this (redundant) implementation.

member.name: T:Nest.IStandardTokenizer
member.summary:
A tokenizer of type standard providing grammar based tokenizer that is a good tokenizer for most European language documents.
The tokenizer implements the Unicode Text Segmentation algorithm, as specified in Unicode Standard Annex #29.

member.name: P:Nest.IStandardTokenizer.MaxTokenLength
member.summary: The maximum token length. If a token is seen that exceeds this length then it is discarded. Defaults to 255.

member.summary: The maximum token length. If a token is seen that exceeds this length then it is discarded. Defaults to 255.

member.summary: A tokenizer of type pattern that can flexibly separate text into terms via a regular expression. Part of the `analysis-kuromoji` plugin: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/plugins/current/analysis-kuromoji.html

member.name: M:Nest.TokenizersDescriptor.Icu(System.String,System.Func{Nest.IcuTokenizerDescriptor,Nest.IIcuTokenizer})
member.summary: Tokenizes text into words on word boundaries, as defined in UAX #29: Unicode Text Segmentation. It behaves much like the standard tokenizer, but adds better support for some Asian languages by using a dictionary-based approach to identify words in Thai, Lao, Chinese, Japanese, and Korean, and using custom rules to break Myanmar and Khmer text into syllables. Part of the `analysis-icu` plugin: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/plugins/current/analysis-icu.html

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.ReloadSecureSettings(System.Func{Nest.ReloadSecureSettingsDescriptor,Nest.IReloadSecureSettingsRequest})
member.summary:
This API will decrypt and re-read the entire keystore, on every cluster node, but only the reloadable secure settings will be applied.
Changes to other settings will not go into effect until the next restart. Once the call returns, the reload has been completed, meaning that all internal datastructures dependent on these settings have been changed. Everything should look as if the settings had the new value from the start.
When changing multiple reloadable secure settings, modify all of them, on each cluster node, and then issue a reload_secure_settings call, instead of reloading after each modification.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.ReloadSecureSettings(Nest.IReloadSecureSettingsRequest)
member.summary:
This API will decrypt and re-read the entire keystore, on every cluster node, but only the reloadable secure settings will be applied.
Changes to other settings will not go into effect until the next restart. Once the call returns, the reload has been completed, meaning that all internal datastructures dependent on these settings have been changed. Everything should look as if the settings had the new value from the start.
When changing multiple reloadable secure settings, modify all of them, on each cluster node, and then issue a reload_secure_settings call, instead of reloading after each modification.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.Update``1(Nest.DocumentPath{``0},System.Func{Nest.UpdateDescriptor{``0,``0},Nest.IUpdateRequest{``0,``0}})
member.summary:
The update API allows to update a document based on a script provided.
The operation gets the document (collocated with the shard) from the index, runs the script (with optional script language and parameters), and index back the result (also allows to delete, or ignore the operation).
It uses versioning to make sure no updates have happened during the "get" and "reindex".
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/docs-update.html
member.typeparam: The type to describe the document to be updated
member.param: a descriptor that describes the update operation

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.Alias(System.Func{Nest.BulkAliasDescriptor,Nest.IBulkAliasRequest})
member.summary:
APIs in elasticsearch accept an index name when working against a specific index, and several indices when applicable.
The index aliases API allow to alias an index with a name, with all APIs automatically converting the alias name to the actual index name.
An alias can also be mapped to more than one index, and when specifying it, the alias will automatically expand to the aliases indices.i
An alias can also be associated with a filter that will automatically be applied when searching, and routing values.
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-aliases.html
member.param: A descriptor that describes the parameters for the alias operation

An alias can also be associated with a filter that will automatically be applied when searching, and routing values.
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-aliases.html
member.param: A descriptor that describes the parameters for the alias operation

member.summary:
The flush API allows to flush one or more indices through an API. The flush process of an index basically frees memory from the index by flushing data to the index storage and clearing the internal transaction log. By default, Elasticsearch uses memory heuristics in order to automatically trigger flush operations as required in order to clear memory.
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-flush.html
member.param: A descriptor that describes the parameters for the flush operation

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.Scroll``1(Nest.IScrollRequest)
member.summary:
A search request can be scrolled by specifying the scroll parameter.
The scroll parameter is a time value parameter (for example: scroll=5m), indicating for how long the nodes that participate in the search will maintain relevant resources in order to continue and support it.
This is very similar in its idea to opening a cursor against a database.
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/search-request-scroll.html
member.typeparam: The type that represents the result hits
member.param: A descriptor that describes the scroll operation
member.returns: A query response holding hits as well as the ScrollId for the next scroll operation

member.summary: Gets follower stats. Returns shard-level stats about the following tasks associated with each shard for the specified indices.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.PauseFollowIndex(Nest.IndexName,System.Func{Nest.PauseFollowIndexDescriptor,Nest.IPauseFollowIndexRequest})
member.summary: Pauses a follower index. When this API returns, the follower index will not fetch any additional operations from the leader index. You can resume following with the resume follower API. Pausing and resuming a follower index can be used to change the configuration of the following task.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.PauseFollowIndex(Nest.IPauseFollowIndexRequest)
member.summary: Pauses a follower index. When this API returns, the follower index will not fetch any additional operations from the leader index. You can resume following with the resume follower API. Pausing and resuming a follower index can be used to change the configuration of the following task.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.ResumeFollowIndex(Nest.IndexName,System.Func{Nest.ResumeFollowIndexDescriptor,Nest.IResumeFollowIndexRequest})
member.summary: Resumes a follower index that has been paused either explicitly with the pause follower API or implicitly due to execution that can not be retried due to failure during following. When this API returns, the follower index will resume fetching operations from the leader index.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.ResumeFollowIndex(Nest.IResumeFollowIndexRequest)
member.summary: Resumes a follower index that has been paused either explicitly with the pause follower API or implicitly due to execution that can not be retried due to failure during following. When this API returns, the follower index will resume fetching operations from the leader index.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.UnfollowIndex(Nest.IndexName,System.Func{Nest.UnfollowIndexDescriptor,Nest.IUnfollowIndexRequest})
member.summary: Stops the following task associated with a follower index and removes index metadata and settings associated with cross-cluster replication. This enables the index to treated as a regular index. The follower index must be paused and closed before invoking the unfollow API.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.UnfollowIndex(Nest.IUnfollowIndexRequest)
member.summary: Stops the following task associated with a follower index and removes index metadata and settings associated with cross-cluster replication. This enables the index to treated as a regular index. The follower index must be paused and closed before invoking the unfollow API.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.CcrStats(System.Func{Nest.CcrStatsDescriptor,Nest.ICcrStatsRequest})
member.summary: Gets cross-cluster replication stats. This API will return all stats related to cross-cluster replication. In particular, this API returns stats about auto-following, and returns the same shard-level stats as in the get follower stats API.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.CcrStats(Nest.ICcrStatsRequest)
member.summary: Gets cross-cluster replication stats. This API will return all stats related to cross-cluster replication. In particular, this API returns stats about auto-following, and returns the same shard-level stats as in the get follower stats API.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.DeleteLifecycle(Nest.PolicyId,System.Func{Nest.DeleteLifecycleDescriptor,Nest.IDeleteLifecycleRequest})
member.summary: Deletes a lifecycle policy. Deletes the specified lifecycle policy definition. You cannot delete policies that are currently in use. If the policy is being used to manage any indices, the request fails and returns an error.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.DeleteLifecycle(Nest.IDeleteLifecycleRequest)
member.summary: Deletes a lifecycle policy. Deletes the specified lifecycle policy definition. You cannot delete policies that are currently in use. If the policy is being used to manage any indices, the request fails and returns an error.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.ExplainLifecycle(Nest.IndexName,System.Func{Nest.ExplainLifecycleDescriptor,Nest.IExplainLifecycleRequest})
member.summary: Shows an index’s current lifecycle status. Retrieves information about the index’s current lifecycle state, such as the currently executing phase, action, and step. Shows when the index entered each one, the definition of the running phase, and information about any failures.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.ExplainLifecycle(Nest.IExplainLifecycleRequest)
member.summary: Shows an index’s current lifecycle status. Retrieves information about the index’s current lifecycle state, such as the currently executing phase, action, and step. Shows when the index entered each one, the definition of the running phase, and information about any failures.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetLifecycle(System.Func{Nest.GetLifecycleDescriptor,Nest.IGetLifecycleRequest})
member.summary: Retrieves a lifecycle policy. Returns the specified policy definition. Includes the policy version and last modified date. If no policy is specified, returns all defined policies.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetLifecycle(Nest.IGetLifecycleRequest)
member.summary: Retrieves a lifecycle policy. Returns the specified policy definition. Includes the policy version and last modified date. If no policy is specified, returns all defined policies.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetIlmStatus(System.Func{Nest.GetIlmStatusDescriptor,Nest.IGetIlmStatusRequest})
member.summary: Retrieves the current index lifecycle management (ILM) status. You can change the status of the ILM plugin with the Start ILM and Stop ILM APIs.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetIlmStatus(Nest.IGetIlmStatusRequest)
member.summary: Retrieves the current index lifecycle management (ILM) status. You can change the status of the ILM plugin with the Start ILM and Stop ILM APIs.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.MoveToStep(Nest.IndexName,System.Func{Nest.MoveToStepDescriptor,Nest.IMoveToStepRequest})
member.summary: Triggers execution of a specific step in the lifecycle policy. Manually moves an index into the specified step and executes that step. You must specify both the current step and the step to be executed in the body of the request. The request will fail if the current step does not match the step currently being executed for the index. This is to prevent the index from being moved from an unexpected step into the next step.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.MoveToStep(Nest.IMoveToStepRequest)
member.summary: Triggers execution of a specific step in the lifecycle policy. Manually moves an index into the specified step and executes that step. You must specify both the current step and the step to be executed in the body of the request. The request will fail if the current step does not match the step currently being executed for the index. This is to prevent the index from being moved from an unexpected step into the next step.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.PutLifecycle(Nest.PolicyId,System.Func{Nest.PutLifecycleDescriptor,Nest.IPutLifecycleRequest})
member.summary: Creates or updates lifecycle policy. Creates a lifecycle policy. If the specified policy exists, the policy is replaced and the policy version is incremented.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.PutLifecycle(Nest.IPutLifecycleRequest)
member.summary: Creates or updates lifecycle policy. Creates a lifecycle policy. If the specified policy exists, the policy is replaced and the policy version is incremented.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.RemovePolicy(Nest.IndexName,System.Func{Nest.RemovePolicyDescriptor,Nest.IRemovePolicyRequest})
member.summary: Removes the assigned lifecycle policy from an index. Removes the assigned lifecycle policy and stops managing the specified index. If an index pattern is specified, removes the assigned policies from all matching indices.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.RemovePolicy(Nest.IRemovePolicyRequest)
member.summary: Removes the assigned lifecycle policy from an index. Removes the assigned lifecycle policy and stops managing the specified index. If an index pattern is specified, removes the assigned policies from all matching indices.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.RetryIlm(Nest.IndexName,System.Func{Nest.RetryIlmDescriptor,Nest.IRetryIlmRequest})
member.summary: Retry executing the policy for an index that is in the ERROR step. Sets the policy back to the step where the error occurred and executes the step. Use the Explain API to determine if an index is in the ERROR step.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.RetryIlm(Nest.IRetryIlmRequest)
member.summary: Retry executing the policy for an index that is in the ERROR step. Sets the policy back to the step where the error occurred and executes the step. Use the Explain API to determine if an index is in the ERROR step.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.StartIlm(System.Func{Nest.StartIlmDescriptor,Nest.IStartIlmRequest})
member.summary: Start the index lifecycle management (ILM) plugin. Starts the ILM plugin if it is currently stopped. ILM is started automatically when the cluster is formed. Restarting ILM is only necessary if it has been stopped using the Stop ILM API.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.StartIlm(Nest.IStartIlmRequest)
member.summary: Start the index lifecycle management (ILM) plugin. Starts the ILM plugin if it is currently stopped. ILM is started automatically when the cluster is formed. Restarting ILM is only necessary if it has been stopped using the Stop ILM API.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.StopIlm(System.Func{Nest.StopIlmDescriptor,Nest.IStopIlmRequest})
member.summary: Stop the index lifecycle management (ILM) plugin. Halts all lifecycle management operations and stops the ILM plugin. This is useful when you are performing maintenance on the cluster and need to prevent ILM from performing any actions on your indices. The API returns as soon as the stop request has been acknowledged, but the plugin might continue to run until in-progress operations complete and the plugin can be safely stopped. Use the Get ILM Status API to see if ILM is running.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.StopIlm(Nest.IStopIlmRequest)
member.summary: Stop the index lifecycle management (ILM) plugin. Halts all lifecycle management operations and stops the ILM plugin. This is useful when you are performing maintenance on the cluster and need to prevent ILM from performing any actions on your indices. The API returns as soon as the stop request has been acknowledged, but the plugin might continue to run until in-progress operations complete and the plugin can be safely stopped. Use the Get ILM Status API to see if ILM is running.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetBasicLicenseStatus(System.Func{Nest.GetBasicLicenseStatusDescriptor,Nest.IGetBasicLicenseStatusRequest})
member.summary: This API enables you to check the status of your basic license

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetTrialLicenseStatus(System.Func{Nest.GetTrialLicenseStatusDescriptor,Nest.IGetTrialLicenseStatusRequest})

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetRollupCapabilities(System.Func{Nest.GetRollupCapabilitiesDescriptor,Nest.IGetRollupCapabilitiesRequest})
member.summary:
Gets the rollup capabilities that have been configured for an index or index pattern. This API is useful because a rollup job is often configured to rollup only a subset of fields from the source index. Furthermore, only certain aggregations can be configured for various fields, leading to a limited subset of functionality depending on that configuration.
This API will allow you to inspect an index and determine:
1. Does this index have associated rollup data somewhere in the cluster?
2. If yes to the first question, what fields were rolled up, what aggregations can be performed, and where does the data live?

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetRollupCapabilities(Nest.IGetRollupCapabilitiesRequest)
member.summary:
Gets the rollup capabilities that have been configured for an index or index pattern. This API is useful because a rollup job is often configured to rollup only a subset of fields from the source index. Furthermore, only certain aggregations can be configured for various fields, leading to a limited subset of functionality depending on that configuration.
This API will allow you to inspect an index and determine:
1. Does this index have associated rollup data somewhere in the cluster?
2. If yes to the first question, what fields were rolled up, what aggregations can be performed, and where does the data live?

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetRollupJob(System.Func{Nest.GetRollupJobDescriptor,Nest.IGetRollupJobRequest})
member.summary:
Gets the configuration, stats and status of rollup jobs. It can return the details for a single job, or for all jobs.
This API only returns active (both STARTED and STOPPED) jobs. If a job was created, ran for a while then deleted, this API will not return any details about that job.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.GetRollupJob(Nest.IGetRollupJobRequest)
member.summary:
Gets the configuration, stats and status of rollup jobs. It can return the details for a single job, or for all jobs.
This API only returns active (both STARTED and STOPPED) jobs. If a job was created, ran for a while then deleted, this API will not return any details about that job.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.RollupSearch``1(Nest.Indices,System.Func{Nest.RollupSearchDescriptor{``0},Nest.IRollupSearchRequest})
member.summary: Searches rolled-up data using the standard query DSL. The Rollup Search endpoint is needed because, internally, rolled-up documents utilize a different document structure than the original data. The Rollup Search endpoint rewrites standard query DSL into a format that matches the rollup documents, then takes the response and rewrites it back to what a client would expect given the original query.

member.name: M:Nest.IElasticClient.RollupSearch``1(Nest.IRollupSearchRequest)
member.summary: Searches rolled-up data using the standard query DSL. The Rollup Search endpoint is needed because, internally, rolled-up documents utilize a different document structure than the original data. The Rollup Search endpoint rewrites standard query DSL into a format that matches the rollup documents, then takes the response and rewrites it back to what a client would expect given the original query.

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.ReloadSecureSettings(System.Func{Nest.ReloadSecureSettingsDescriptor,Nest.IReloadSecureSettingsRequest})
member.summary:
This API will decrypt and re-read the entire keystore, on every cluster node, but only the reloadable secure settings will be applied.
Changes to other settings will not go into effect until the next restart. Once the call returns, the reload has been completed, meaning that all internal datastructures dependent on these settings have been changed. Everything should look as if the settings had the new value from the start.
When changing multiple reloadable secure settings, modify all of them, on each cluster node, and then issue a reload_secure_settings call, instead of reloading after each modification.

member.summary: Creates a new typed document in a specific index. If a document with the same index, type and id already exists, A 409 Conflict HTTP response status code and error will be returned.
member.typeparam: The document type used to infer the default index, type and id
member.param:
The document to be created. Id will be inferred from (in order):
1. Id property set up on for
2. property on applied to
3. A property named Id on
Optionally further describe the create operation i.e override type/index/id

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.Update``1(Nest.DocumentPath{``0},System.Func{Nest.UpdateDescriptor{``0,``0},Nest.IUpdateRequest{``0,``0}})
member.summary:
The update API allows to update a document based on a script provided.
The operation gets the document (collocated with the shard) from the index, runs the script (with optional script language and parameters), and index back the result (also allows to delete, or ignore the operation).
It uses versioning to make sure no updates have happened during the "get" and "reindex".
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/docs-update.html
member.typeparam: The type to describe the document to be updated
member.param: a descriptor that describes the update operation

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.Alias(Nest.IBulkAliasRequest)
member.summary:
APIs in elasticsearch accept an index name when working against a specific index, and several indices when applicable.
The index aliases API allow to alias an index with a name, with all APIs automatically converting the alias name to the actual index name.
An alias can also be mapped to more than one index, and when specifying it, the alias will automatically expand to the aliases indices.i
An alias can also be associated with a filter that will automatically be applied when searching, and routing values.
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-aliases.html
member.param: A descriptor that describes the parameters for the alias operation

An alias can also be associated with a filter that will automatically be applied when searching, and routing values.

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.GetAlias(System.Func{Nest.GetAliasDescriptor,Nest.IGetAliasRequest})
member.summary:
The get index alias api allows to filter by alias name and index name. This api redirects to the master and fetches the requested index aliases, if available. This api only serialises the found index aliases.
Difference with GetAlias is that this call will also return indices without aliases set
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-aliases.html#alias-retrieving
member.param: A descriptor that describes which aliases/indexes we are interested int

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.CloseIndex(Nest.Indices,System.Func{Nest.CloseIndexDescriptor,Nest.ICloseIndexRequest})
member.summary:
The open and close index APIs allow to close an index, and later on opening it. A closed index has almost no overhead on the cluster (except for maintaining its metadata), and is blocked for read/write operations. A closed index can be opened which will then go through the normal recovery process.
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-open-close.html
member.param: A descriptor thata describes the close index operation

The templates include both settings and mappings, and a simple pattern template that controls if the template will be applied to the index created.

member.summary:
Provide low level segments information that a Lucene index (shard level) is built with. Allows to be used to provide more information on the state of a shard and an index, possibly optimization information, data "wasted" on deletes, and so on.
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-segments.html
member.param: A descriptor that describes the parameters for the segments operation

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.Flush(Nest.Indices,System.Func{Nest.FlushDescriptor,Nest.IFlushRequest})
member.summary:
The flush API allows to flush one or more indices through an API. The flush process of an index basically frees memory from the index by flushing data to the index storage and clearing the internal transaction log. By default, Elasticsearch uses memory heuristics in order to automatically trigger flush operations as required in order to clear memory.
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/indices-flush.html
member.param: A descriptor that describes the parameters for the flush operation

member.param: A descriptor that describes the parameters for the flush operation

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.Scroll``1(Nest.IScrollRequest)
member.summary:
A search request can be scrolled by specifying the scroll parameter.
The scroll parameter is a time value parameter (for example: scroll=5m), indicating for how long the nodes that participate in the search will maintain relevant resources in order to continue and support it.
This is very similar in its idea to opening a cursor against a database.
http://www.elasticsearch.org/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/search-request-scroll.html
member.typeparam: The type that represents the result hits
member.param: A descriptor that describes the scroll operation
member.returns: A query response holding hits as well as the ScrollId for the next scroll operation

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.PauseFollowIndex(Nest.IndexName,System.Func{Nest.PauseFollowIndexDescriptor,Nest.IPauseFollowIndexRequest})
member.summary: Pauses a follower index. When this API returns, the follower index will not fetch any additional operations from the leader index. You can resume following with the resume follower API. Pausing and resuming a follower index can be used to change the configuration of the following task.

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.MoveToStep(Nest.IndexName,System.Func{Nest.MoveToStepDescriptor,Nest.IMoveToStepRequest})
member.summary: Triggers execution of a specific step in the lifecycle policy. Manually moves an index into the specified step and executes that step. You must specify both the current step and the step to be executed in the body of the request. The request will fail if the current step does not match the step currently being executed for the index. This is to prevent the index from being moved from an unexpected step into the next step.

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.StartIlm(System.Func{Nest.StartIlmDescriptor,Nest.IStartIlmRequest})
member.summary: Start the index lifecycle management (ILM) plugin. Starts the ILM plugin if it is currently stopped. ILM is started automatically when the cluster is formed. Restarting ILM is only necessary if it has been stopped using the Stop ILM API.

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.StopIlm(System.Func{Nest.StopIlmDescriptor,Nest.IStopIlmRequest})
member.summary: Stop the index lifecycle management (ILM) plugin. Halts all lifecycle management operations and stops the ILM plugin. This is useful when you are performing maintenance on the cluster and need to prevent ILM from performing any actions on your indices. The API returns as soon as the stop request has been acknowledged, but the plugin might continue to run until in-progress operations complete and the plugin can be safely stopped. Use the Get ILM Status API to see if ILM is running.

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.StopIlm(Nest.IStopIlmRequest)

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.StartBasicLicense(System.Func{Nest.StartBasicLicenseDescriptor,Nest.IStartBasicLicenseRequest})
member.summary: The start basic API enables you to initiate an indefinite basic license, which gives access to all of the basic features. If the basic license does not support all of the features that are available with your current license, however, you are notified in the response. You must then re-submit the API request with the acknowledge parameter set to true.

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.GetRollupCapabilities(System.Func{Nest.GetRollupCapabilitiesDescriptor,Nest.IGetRollupCapabilitiesRequest})
member.summary:
Gets the rollup capabilities that have been configured for an index or index pattern. This API is useful because a rollup job is often configured to rollup only a subset of fields from the source index. Furthermore, only certain aggregations can be configured for various fields, leading to a limited subset of functionality depending on that configuration.
This API will allow you to inspect an index and determine:
1. Does this index have associated rollup data somewhere in the cluster?
2. If yes to the first question, what fields were rolled up, what aggregations can be performed, and where does the data live?

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.GetRollupJob(System.Func{Nest.GetRollupJobDescriptor,Nest.IGetRollupJobRequest})
member.summary:
Gets the configuration, stats and status of rollup jobs. It can return the details for a single job, or for all jobs.
This API only returns active (both STARTED and STOPPED) jobs. If a job was created, ran for a while then deleted, this API will not return any details about that job.

member.name: M:Nest.ElasticClient.RollupSearch``1(Nest.Indices,System.Func{Nest.RollupSearchDescriptor{``0},Nest.IRollupSearchRequest})
member.summary: Searches rolled-up data using the standard query DSL. The Rollup Search endpoint is needed because, internally, rolled-up documents utilize a different document structure than the original data. The Rollup Search endpoint rewrites standard query DSL into a format that matches the rollup documents, then takes the response and rewrites it back to what a client would expect given the original query.

member.summary:
Disables automatic Id inference for given CLR types.

member.name: P:Nest.IConnectionSettingsValues.DefaultDisableIdInference
member.summary:
Disables automatic Id inference for all CLR types.

member.name: T:Nest.IResponse
member.summary: Shared interface by all elasticsearch responses

member.name: P:Nest.IResponse.DebugInformation
member.summary: A lazy human readable string representation of what happened during this request for both successful and failed requests, very useful while developing or to log when is false on responses.

member.name: P:Nest.IResponse.IsValid
member.summary:
This property can be used to check if a response is functionally valid or not. This is a NEST abstraction to have a single point to check whether something wrong happened with the request.
For instance an elasticsearch bulk response always returns 200 and individual bulk items may fail, will be false in that case
You can also configure the client to always throw an using if the response is not valid

member.name: P:Nest.IResponse.OriginalException
member.summary:
If the request resulted in an exception on the client side this will hold the exception that was thrown.
This property is a shortcut to 's and is possibly set when is false depending on the cause of the error
You can also configure the client to always throw an using if the response is not valid

member.name: P:Nest.IResponse.ServerError
member.summary:
If the response results in an error on elasticsearch's side an error element will be returned, this is mapped to in NEST.
Possibly set when is false, depending on the cause of the error
You can also configure the client to always throw an using if the response is not valid

member.name: T:Nest.JsonConverterPiggyBackState
member.summary: Registering global JsonConverter is very costly, The best thing is to specify them as a contract (see ElasticContractResolver) This however prevents a way to give a JsonConverter state which for some calls is needed i.e: A multiget and multisearch need access to the descriptor that describes what types are used. When NEST knows it has to piggyback this it has to pass serialization state it will create a new serializersettings object with a new contract resolver which holds this state. Its ugly but it does boost massive performance gains.

member.name: P:Nest.BulkRequest.Refresh
member.summary: If `true` then refresh the effected shards to make this operation visible to search, if `wait_for` then wait for a refresh to make this operation visible to search, if `false` (the default) then do nothing with refreshes.

member.name: P:Nest.BulkRequest.Routing
member.summary:
A document is routed to a particular shard in an index using the following formula
shard_num = hash(_routing) % num_primary_shards
Elasticsearch will use the document id if not provided.
For requests that are constructed from/for a document NEST will automatically infer the routing key if that document has a or a routing mapping on for its type exists on

member.name: M:Nest.BulkDescriptor.WaitForActiveShards(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the number of shard copies that must be active before proceeding with the bulk operation. Defaults to 1, meaning the primary shard only. Set to `all` for all shard copies, otherwise set to any non-negative value less than or equal to the total number of copies for the shard (number of replicas + 1)

member.name: M:Nest.BulkDescriptor.Refresh(System.Nullable{Elasticsearch.Net.Refresh})
member.summary: If `true` then refresh the effected shards to make this operation visible to search, if `wait_for` then wait for a refresh to make this operation visible to search, if `false` (the default) then do nothing with refreshes.

member.name: M:Nest.BulkDescriptor.Routing(Nest.Routing)
member.summary:
A document is routed to a particular shard in an index using the following formula
shard_num = hash(_routing) % num_primary_shards
Elasticsearch will use the document id if not provided.
For requests that are constructed from/for a document NEST will automatically infer the routing key if that document has a or a routing mapping on for its type exists on

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.Stats(System.String[])
member.summary: Specific 'tag' of the request for logging and statistical purposes

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.Version(System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Specify whether to return document version as part of a hit

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.RequestCache(System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Specify if request cache should be used for this request or not, defaults to index level setting

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.Refresh(System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Should the effected indexes be refreshed?

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.Timeout(Nest.Time)
member.summary: Time each individual bulk request should wait for shards that are unavailable.

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.WaitForActiveShards(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the number of shard copies that must be active before proceeding with the delete by query operation. Defaults to 1, meaning the primary shard only. Set to `all` for all shard copies, otherwise set to any non-negative value less than or equal to the total number of copies for the shard (number of replicas + 1)

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.ScrollSize(System.Nullable{System.Int64})
member.summary: Size on the scroll request powering the delete by query

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.WaitForCompletion(System.Nullable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Should the request should block until the delete by query is complete.

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.RequestsPerSecond(System.Nullable{System.Int64})
member.summary: The throttle for this request in sub-requests per second. -1 means no throttle.

member.name: M:Nest.DeleteByQueryDescriptor`1.Slices(System.Nullable{System.Int64})
member.summary: The number of slices this task should be divided into. Defaults to 1 meaning the task isn't sliced into subtasks.

member.name: P:Nest.IDeleteByQueryResponse.Task
member.summary: Only has a value if WaitForCompletion is set to false on the request

member.summary: Refresh the shard containing the document before performing the operation

member.name: P:Nest.MultiGetRequest.Routing
member.summary:
A document is routed to a particular shard in an index using the following formula
shard_num = hash(_routing) % num_primary_shards
Elasticsearch will use the document id if not provided.
For requests that are constructed from/for a document NEST will automatically infer the routing key if that document has a or a routing mapping on for its type exists on

member.summary: Whether the _source should be included in the response.

member.summary: A list of fields to extract and return from the _source field

member.name: T:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation
member.summary: An operation to define the calculation of term vectors when using Multi termvectors API

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.Document
member.summary: A document not indexed in Elasticsearch, to generate term vectors for

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.FieldStatistics
member.summary:
Whether to include field statistics. When set to false,
- document count (how many documents contain this field)
- sum of document frequencies (the sum of document frequencies for all terms in this field)
- sum of total term frequencies (the sum of total term frequencies of each term in this field)
will be omitted. Default is true.

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.Filter
member.summary: Filter terms based on their tf-idf scores. This can be useful in order find out a good characteristic vector of a document.

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.Id
member.summary: The id of the document

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.Index
member.summary: The index in which the document resides

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.Offsets
member.summary: Whether to include the start and end offsets. Default is true.

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.Payloads
member.summary: Whether to include the term payloads as base64 encoded bytes. Default is true

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.Positions
member.summary: Whether to include the term positions. Default is true

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.Routing
member.summary: When requesting term vectors for , a shard to get the statistics from is randomly selected. Use only to hit a particular shard.

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.StoredFields
member.summary: The document field to generate term vectors for

member.name: P:Nest.IMultiTermVectorOperation.TermStatistics
member.summary:
Whether to include term statistics. When set to true,
- total term frequency (how often a term occurs in all documents)
- document frequency (the number of documents containing the current term)
will be returned. Default is false since term statistics can have a large performance impact.

member.summary: The type of the document

member.name: T:Nest.IReindexRequest`2
member.summary:
A reindex implementation that uses ScrollAll() BulkAll() to compose a reindex pipeline.
This differs from ReindexOnServer() in that documents are fetched from Elasticsearch, transformed on the client side, then sent back to Elasticsearch.
This will create the target index if it doesn't exist already. If is not specified and the source of the reindex points to a single index we try and reuse the settings from source. You can completely opt out of all of this using

member.name: P:Nest.IReindexRequest`2.BackPressureFactor
member.summary:
The scroll typically outperforms the bulk operations by a long shot. If we'd leave things unbounded you'd quickly have way too many pending scroll requests. What this property allows you to express is that for each bucket in the max concurrency of the minimum max concurrency between producer and consumer amply the maximum overal pending of the other side by this factor. Typically the concurrency of the consumer (bulkall) will be lower and with this factor we can dampen the overall pending scroll requests while we are still processing bulk requests.
defaults to 4 if not provided

member.name: P:Nest.IReindexRequest`2.BulkAll
member.summary:
Provide a factory for the bulk all request, the first argument is the lazy collection of scroll results which is a mandatory argument to create or
Note that is always overriden as well as

member.name: P:Nest.IReindexRequest`2.CreateIndexRequest
member.summary: Describe how the newly created index should be created. Remember you can also register Index Templates for more dynamic usecases.

member.name: P:Nest.IReindexRequest`2.OmitIndexCreation
member.summary: Do not send a create index call on the target index, assume the index has been created outside of the reindex. Reindex will never create the index if it already exists however this will also omit the IndexExists call.

member.name: P:Nest.IReindexRequest`2.ScrollAll
member.summary:
Describes the scroll operation where we need to fetch the documents from.
Note that can be overriden by our own.

member.summary:
The scroll typically outperforms the bulk operations by a long shot. If we'd leave things unbounded you'd quickly have way too many pending scroll requests. What this property allows you to express is that for each bucket in the max concurrency of the minimum max concurrency between producer and consumer amply the maximum overal pending of the other side by this factor. Typically the concurrency of the consumer (bulkall) will be lower and with this factor we can dampen the overall pending scroll requests while we are still processing bulk requests.
defaults to 4 if not provided

member.name: P:Nest.IScrollAllRequest.BackPressure
member.summary: Simple back pressure implementation that makes sure the minimum max concurrency between producer and consumer is not amplified by the greedier of the two by more then a given back pressure factor When set each scroll request will additionally wait on as well as if set. Not that the consumer has to call on the same instance every time it is done.

member.name: P:Nest.UpdateByQueryRequest.Routing
member.summary:
A document is routed to a particular shard in an index using the following formula
shard_num = hash(_routing) % num_primary_shards
Elasticsearch will use the document id if not provided.
For requests that are constructed from/for a document NEST will automatically infer the routing key if that document has a or a routing mapping on for its type exists on

member.name: P:Nest.UpdateByQueryRequest`1.WaitForActiveShards

member.name: M:Nest.UpdateByQueryDescriptor`1.Routing(Nest.Routing)
member.summary:
A document is routed to a particular shard in an index using the following formula
shard_num = hash(_routing) % num_primary_shards
Elasticsearch will use the document id if not provided.
For requests that are constructed from/for a document NEST will automatically infer the routing key if that document has a or a routing mapping on for its type exists on

member.name: P:Nest.IndexRequest`1.WaitForActiveShards
member.summary: Sets the number of shard copies that must be active before proceeding with the index operation. Defaults to 1, meaning the primary shard only. Set to `all` for all shard copies, otherwise set to any non-negative value less than or equal to the total number of copies for the shard (number of replicas + 1)

member.summary: Explicit operation type

member.summary: ID of the parent document

member.name: P:Nest.IndexRequest`1.Refresh
member.summary: If `true` then refresh the affected shards to make this operation visible to search, if `wait_for` then wait for a refresh to make this operation visible to search, if `false` (the default) then do nothing with refreshes.

member.name: P:Nest.IndexRequest`1.Routing
member.summary:
A document is routed to a particular shard in an index using the following formula
shard_num = hash(_routing) % num_primary_shards
Elasticsearch will use the document id if not provided.
For requests that are constructed from/for a document NEST will automatically infer the routing key if that document has a or a routing mapping on for its type exists on

member.summary: Sets the number of shard copies that must be active before proceeding with the update operation. Defaults to 1, meaning the primary shard only. member.name: P:Nest.IMergePolicySettings.ExpungeDeletesAllowed
member.summary: When expungeDeletes is called, we only merge away a segment if its delete percentage is over this threshold. Default is 10.

member.name: P:Nest.IMergePolicySettings.FloorSegment
member.summary: Segments smaller than this are "rounded up" to this size, i.e. treated as equal (floor) size for merge selection. This is to prevent frequent flushing of tiny segments, thus preventing a long tail in the index. Default is 2mb.

member.name: P:Nest.IMergePolicySettings.MaxMergeAtOnce
member.summary: Maximum number of segments to be merged at a time during "normal" merging. Default is 10.

member.name: P:Nest.IMergePolicySettings.MaxMergeAtOnceExplicit
member.summary: Maximum number of segments to be merged at a time, during optimize or expungeDeletes. Default is 30.

member.name: P:Nest.IMergePolicySettings.MaxMergedSegment
member.summary: Maximum sized segment to produce during normal merging (not explicit optimize). This setting is approximate: the estimate of the merged segment size is made by summing sizes of to-be-merged segments (compensating for percent deleted docs). Default is 5gb.

member.name: P:Nest.IMergePolicySettings.ReclaimDeletesWeight
member.summary: Controls how aggressively merges that reclaim more deletions are favored. Higher values favor selecting merges that reclaim deletions. A value of 0.0 means deletions don’t impact merge selection. Defaults to 2.0

member.name: P:Nest.IMergePolicySettings.SegmentsPerTier
member.summary: Sets the allowed number of segments per tier. Smaller values mean more merging but fewer segments. Default is 10. Note, this value needs to be >= than the max_merge_at_once otherwise you’ll force too many merges to occur.

member.name: P:Nest.MergePolicySettings.ExpungeDeletesAllowed
member.summary: When expungeDeletes is called, we only merge away a segment if its delete percentage is over this threshold. Default is 10.

member.name: P:Nest.MergePolicySettings.FloorSegment
member.summary: Segments smaller than this are "rounded up" to this size, i.e. treated as equal (floor) size for merge selection. This is to prevent frequent flushing of tiny segments, thus preventing a long tail in the index. Default is 2mb.

member.name: P:Nest.MergePolicySettings.MaxMergeAtOnce
member.summary: Maximum number of segments to be merged at a time during "normal" merging. Default is 10.

member.name: P:Nest.MergePolicySettings.MaxMergeAtOnceExplicit
member.summary: Maximum number of segments to be merged at a time, during optimize or expungeDeletes. Default is 30.

member.name: P:Nest.MergePolicySettings.MaxMergedSegment
member.summary: Maximum sized segment to produce during normal merging (not explicit optimize). This setting is approximate: the estimate of the merged segment size is made by summing sizes of to-be-merged segments (compensating for percent deleted docs). Default is 5gb.

member.name: P:Nest.MergePolicySettings.ReclaimDeletesWeight
member.summary: Controls how aggressively merges that reclaim more deletions are favored. Higher values favor selecting merges that reclaim deletions. A value of 0.0 means deletions don’t impact merge selection. Defaults to 2.0

member.name: P:Nest.MergePolicySettings.SegmentsPerTier
member.summary: Sets the allowed number of segments per tier. Smaller values mean more merging but fewer segments. Default is 10. Note, this value needs to be >= than the max_merge_at_once otherwise you’ll force too many merges to occur.

member.name: M:Nest.MergePolicySettingsDescriptor.ExpungeDeletesAllowed(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: When expungeDeletes is called, we only merge away a segment if its delete percentage is over this threshold. Default is 10.

member.name: M:Nest.MergePolicySettingsDescriptor.FloorSegment(System.String)
member.summary: Segments smaller than this are "rounded up" to this size, i.e. treated as equal (floor) size for merge selection. This is to prevent frequent flushing of tiny segments, thus preventing a long tail in the index. Default is 2mb.

member.name: M:Nest.MergePolicySettingsDescriptor.MaxMergeAtOnce(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Maximum number of segments to be merged at a time during "normal" merging. Default is 10.

member.name: M:Nest.MergePolicySettingsDescriptor.MaxMergeAtOnceExplicit(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Maximum number of segments to be merged at a time, during optimize or expungeDeletes. Default is 30.

member.name: M:Nest.MergePolicySettingsDescriptor.ReclaimDeletesWeight(System.Nullable{System.Double})
member.summary: Controls how aggressively merges that reclaim more deletions are favored. Higher values favor selecting merges that reclaim deletions. A value of 0.0 means deletions don’t impact merge selection. Defaults to 2.0

member.name: M:Nest.MergePolicySettingsDescriptor.SegmentsPerTier(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Sets the allowed number of segments per tier. Smaller values mean more merging but fewer segments. Default is 10. Note, this value needs to be >= than the max_merge_at_once otherwise you’ll force too many merges to occur.

member.name: P:Nest.IMergeSchedulerSettings.AutoThrottle
member.summary: If this is true (the default), then the merge scheduler will rate-limit IO (writes) for merges to an adaptive value depending on how many merges are requested over time. An application with a low indexing rate that unluckily suddenly requires a large merge will see that merge aggressively throttled, while an application doing heavy indexing will see the throttle move higher to allow merges to keep up with ongoing indexing.

member.name: P:Nest.IMergeSchedulerSettings.MaxThreadCount
member.summary: The maximum number of threads that may be merging at once. Defaults to Math.max(1, Math.min(4, Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors() / 2)) which works well for a good solid-state-disk (SSD). If your index is on spinning platter drives instead, decrease this to 1.

member.name: P:Nest.MergeSchedulerSettings.AutoThrottle
member.summary: If this is true (the default), then the merge scheduler will rate-limit IO (writes) for merges to an adaptive value depending on how many merges are requested over time. An application with a low indexing rate that unluckily suddenly requires a large merge will see that merge aggressively throttled, while an application doing heavy indexing will see the throttle move higher to allow merges to keep up with ongoing indexing.

member.name: P:Nest.MergeSchedulerSettings.MaxThreadCount

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.AutoExpandReplicas
member.summary: Auto-expand the number of replicas based on the number of available nodes. Set to a dash delimited lower and upper bound (e.g. 0-5) or use all for the upper bound (e.g. 0-all). Defaults to false (i.e. disabled).

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.BlocksMetadata
member.summary: Set to true to disable index metadata reads and writes.

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.BlocksRead
member.summary: Set to true to disable read operations against the index.

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.BlocksReadOnly
member.summary: Set to true to make the index and index metadata read only, false to allow writes and metadata changes.

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.BlocksWrite
member.summary: Set to true to disable write operations against the index.

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.Merge
member.summary: All of the settings exposed in the merge module are expert only and may be obsoleted in the future at any time!

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.NumberOfReplicas
member.summary: The number of replicas each primary shard has. Defaults to 1.

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.Priority
member.summary: Unallocated shards are recovered in order of priority when set

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.RecoveryInitialShards
member.summary: A primary shard is only recovered only if there are enough nodes available to allocate sufficient replicas to form a quorum.

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.RefreshInterval
member.summary: How often to perform a refresh operation, which makes recent changes to the index visible to search. Defaults to 1s. Can be set to -1 to disable refresh.

member.name: P:Nest.IDynamicIndexSettings.RequestsCacheEnabled
member.summary: Enables the shard-level request cache. Not enabled by default.

member.name: T:Nest.FileSystemStorageImplementation
member.summary: The store module allows you to control how index data is stored and accessed on disk.

member.name: F:Nest.FileSystemStorageImplementation.Simple
member.summary: The Simple FS type is a straightforward implementation of file system storage (maps to Lucene SimpleFsDirectory) using a random access file. This implementation has poor concurrent performance (multiple threads will bottleneck). It is usually better to use the niofs when you need index persistence.

member.name: F:Nest.FileSystemStorageImplementation.NIO
member.summary: The NIO FS type stores the shard index on the file system (maps to Lucene NIOFSDirectory) using NIO. It allows multiple threads to read from the same file concurrently. It is not recommended on Windows because of a bug in the SUN Java implementation./

member.name: F:Nest.FileSystemStorageImplementation.MMap
member.summary: The MMap FS type stores the shard index on the file system (maps to Lucene MMapDirectory) by mapping a file into memory (mmap). Memory mapping uses up a portion of the virtual memory address space in your process equal to the size of the file being mapped. Before using this class, be sure you have allowed plenty of virtual address space.

member.name: F:Nest.FileSystemStorageImplementation.Default
member.summary: The default type is a hybrid of NIO FS and MMapFS, which chooses the best file system for each type of file. Currently only the Lucene term dictionary and doc values files are memory mapped to reduce the impact on the operating system. All other files are opened using Lucene NIOFSDirectory.

member.name: F:Nest.DFRAfterEffect.No
member.summary: Implementation used when there is no aftereffect.

member.name: F:Nest.DFRAfterEffect.B
member.summary: Model of the information gain based on the ratio of two Bernoulli processes.

member.name: F:Nest.DFRAfterEffect.L
member.summary: Model of the information gain based on Laplace's law of succession.

member.name: F:Nest.DFRBasicModel.BE
member.summary: Limiting form of the Bose-Einstein model. The formula used in Lucene differs slightly from the one in the original paper: F is increased by tfn+1 and N is increased by F

member.name: F:Nest.DFRBasicModel.D
member.summary: Implements the approximation of the binomial model with the divergence for DFR. The formula used in Lucene differs slightly from the one in the original paper: to avoid underflow for small values of N and F, N is increased by 1 and F is always increased by tfn+1.

member.name: F:Nest.DFRBasicModel.G
member.summary: Geometric as limiting form of the Bose-Einstein model. The formula used in Lucene differs slightly from the one in the original paper: F is increased by 1 and N is increased by F.

member.name: F:Nest.DFRBasicModel.IF
member.summary: An approximation of the I(ne) model.

member.name: F:Nest.DFRBasicModel.IN
member.summary: The basic tf-idf model of randomness.

member.name: F:Nest.DFRBasicModel.INE
member.summary: Tf-idf model of randomness, based on a mixture of Poisson and inverse document frequency.

member.name: F:Nest.DFRBasicModel.P
member.summary: Implements the Poisson approximation for the binomial model for DFR.

member.name: T:Nest.IDFRSimilarity
member.summary: Implements the divergence from randomness (DFR) framework introduced in Gianni Amati and Cornelis Joost Van Rijsbergen. 2002. Probabilistic models of information retrieval based on measuring the divergence from randomness. ACM Trans. Inf. Syst. 20, 4 (October 2002), 357-389. The DFR scoring formula is composed of three separate components: the basic model, the aftereffect and an additional normalization component, represented by the classes BasicModel, AfterEffect and Normalization, respectively.The names of these classes were chosen to match the names of their counterparts in the Terrier IR engine.

member.name: T:Nest.IIBSimilarity
member.summary: Information based model similarity. For written texts this challenge would correspond to comparing the writing styles of different authors.
